review_title: Paid fairly decently, but overworked and unheard
pros: Good pay and overall decent benefits
cons:

Please hire a decent amount of employees for the necessary workload, and make sure that employee concerns are heard and respected,

pros: Pay was great. Management has your back. Benefits were awesome. Overall a good experience.
cons:
Class B drivers were pee-ons. I could be out 11 hours and told to make a second run when I got back...Class A drivers could be out 5 hours and never told to make a second run. Class B trucks were, except for 1, pieces of crap...especially the reefer units. Pay was decent, but no incentive pay or performance pay like the Class A drivers. If I was given a route that was routed for 10 hours and got it done in 8 hours, I was paid for 8 hours! So, the better a job I did, the less I got paid! LOL.
Advice to Management
Give the class b drivers incentive, performance pay like the broad-liners.

review_title: I recently was terminated after a tragic death in my family
pros: Great opportunity to earn a good salary
cons:
After missing a couple of days due to a death in my family I was terminated after only 2 months due to what the company claims as a productivity issue I was told I had 90 days to learn the job and warehouse a d after less than 60 days I was fired for only having 82 to 90 percent percentages for the week and on my last day a 92 % I was terminated
Advice to Management
Be more clearly with new hires on the time actually they have to learn the process and exactly where they should be week to week percentage wise so they cannot be terminated

review_title: Executive Leadership talks the talk, but does not walk the walk
pros: Really great people to work with overall. Unlimited opportunities to assume additional work/responsibilities for professional growth. Many new faces on the executive leadership team that will hopefully be able to implement the ideas they are discussing, particularly related to D&I.
cons:
Quality of individual leaders ranks from really terrible to really great. Pay is low for office workers, and raises/promotions are not granted uniformly. HR is not trusted

Train your leaders on how to be leaders. Most leaders are great at their core functions, but have no skills in actually leading or developing people. D&I focus needs to be more balanced towards equity & inclusion.

pros: Literally nothing. This is not the company to build your IT career
cons:
You will be worked almost to death for ungrateful employees who at every second will look take advantage of you. You will be expected to be “on call” 24/7. You will be responsible for ALL thing that have electricity that have nothing to do with IT! you will be VASTLY under paid for what you do. You will be micromanaged constantly. You will be expected to troubleshoot out dated proprietary software on your first day of working. You will be the ONLY “IT” person on-site (almost 400 users) and last but not least, you will not get your last paycheck. Sysco will claim you were “pro rated” your first check years ago. Not to mention they laid off over 40% of their staff due to covid but “donated” tons to money to other corporations. They preach “family” but the employees work in fear that they will be let go at the moments notice. There are no room for IT advancements.

I left before the IT department is outsourced to India..... again!
Advice to Management
Treat your employees with respect! Do not scam them!

pros: Training is extensive and very good, which sets you up to succeed. Very broad product line, you can pretty much get anything for your customer that they need. Company is known in the restaurant/hotel business. Lots of support for sales staff and continued education on new and existing products.
cons:
You work a LOT. This job is most ideal for a single person who wants to hustle hard and make money. Ideally, you are positioned as your clients' go-to person, and in the restaurant business that means you are fielding a lot of issues, even those that are not your fault. So if a chef has a problem at midnight on a Saturday, you take the call and solve the problem. Once I had kids this lifestyle was not the one for me.

Mangement was always supportive.

review_title: Lots of changes and not for the good
pros: There are some great people you work with and great customers you will service. There is some freedom to the sales job
cons:
On the fly changes, less pay than ever before, management is only looking out for themselves
Advice to Management
I will say I know most companies have had to adjust due to Covid and some of those changes will not work in employees favor. The brand Sysco is not what it used to be. We used to stand out as the best in the business. You got what you paid for with Sysco, products were pristine and the top of the line and trucks showed up with all of your products. Now the sales team is buried with micromanaged agendas and forms to fill out. I understand the programs to monitor and encourage growth but it’s no longer about that. Now before we sell a case of mayo to a customer we have to explain why we want to sell it, how we are going to sell it, what pushed the customer to purchase it and then rinse and repeat. This is no longer about selling groceries but a job is where corporate wants to know what you are doing every second of your day. They have cut everyone’s salary and expect even more now than they ever have. I opened a 10k a week customer and due to new pay structure I did not qualify for a bonus and was unable to make any extra commissions from the sales. I have sold this customer 150k or so worth of product and have yet to receive an extra penny for any of it. Our phones do not stop ringing with problems that include their trucks are 3 hours late, they cannot get what the order and more importantly, we are WAY more expensive than any other vendor and the quality does not justify it. All of the apps that Sysco has rolled out has had tons of problems, at times before cutoff programs will not work so you are forced to call into a 1800 number to where they are overloaded with work and you will wait 30 minutes on the phone. Of all the coworkers I speak with, we ALL HATE our jobs, it’s miserable waking up and going into work and almost all of us have began to look for new jobs. The sales rep is the glue that holds that customer to Sysco in most cases and I can guarantee you that you will be losing customers soon as a mass exodus from Sysco I will begin soon.
Helpful
Sysco Response
October 2, 2020 – Director
Thank you for taking the time to provide feedback.

Sysco associates are the reason why we have become the world’s foodservice distribution leader. We are committed to continuous improvement while upholding our Vision, Values, and Code of Conduct. We take your feedback seriously and welcome you to call us at 877-777-4020 so that we may obtain greater detail regarding your concerns
advice_to_mgmt:
I will say I know most companies have had to adjust due to Covid and some of those changes will not work in employees favor. The brand Sysco is not what it used to be. We used to stand out as the best in the business. You got what you paid for with Sysco, products were pristine and the top of the line and trucks showed up with all of your products. Now the sales team is buried with micromanaged agendas and forms to fill out. I understand the programs to monitor and encourage growth but it’s no longer about that. Now before we sell a case of mayo to a customer we have to explain why we want to sell it, how we are going to sell it, what pushed the customer to purchase it and then rinse and repeat. This is no longer about selling groceries but a job is where corporate wants to know what you are doing every second of your day. They have cut everyone’s salary and expect even more now than they ever have. I opened a 10k a week customer and due to new pay structure I did not qualify for a bonus and was unable to make any extra commissions from the sales. I have sold this customer 150k or so worth of product and have yet to receive an extra penny for any of it. Our phones do not stop ringing with problems that include their trucks are 3 hours late, they cannot get what the order and more importantly, we are WAY more expensive than any other vendor and the quality does not justify it. All of the apps that Sysco has rolled out has had tons of problems, at times before cutoff programs will not work so you are forced to call into a 1800 number to where they are overloaded with work and you will wait 30 minutes on the phone. Of all the coworkers I speak with, we ALL HATE our jobs, it’s miserable waking up and going into work and almost all of us have began to look for new jobs. The sales rep is the glue that holds that customer to Sysco in most cases and I can guarantee you that you will be losing customers soon as a mass exodus from Sysco I will begin soon.
Helpful
Sysco Response
October 2, 2020 – Director
Thank you for taking the time to provide feedback.

Sysco associates are the reason why we have become the world’s foodservice distribution leader. We are committed to continuous improvement while upholding our Vision, Values, and Code of Conduct. We take your feedback seriously and welcome you to call us at 877-777-4020 so that we may obtain greater detail regarding your concerns

review_title: Frustrating good old boy company pretending to be innovative and inclusive
pros: A few of the people I work with are nice. When I first started it was fine but it quickly went downhill and continues downward every single day.
cons:
Pay and benefits are not competitive

Leaders have terrible leadership skills (incompetent, bullying, title snobs, ignore your input, take credit for your ideas, etc.)

Disorganized, confusing, and contradictory policies and procedures

Poor technology

Every department is under staffed and has no budget so everyone is overworked, stressed, and burnt out

Lots of lip service from leaders (don't be fooled by the public statements and social media posts about the diversity efforts - it's all middle aged white men calling the shots; they tell you to take time off and take care of your mental health but load you down with an unreasonable amount of work that means long hours, working on days off, or not being able to use vacation days, which you don't have the option of getting paid out)

HR is nothing but toxic office politics and making excuses for bullies throughout the organization 

Senior leaders are very out of touch with what's really going on in the company - even if multiple people try to tell them, they ignore it or get offended and blow you off

Very male-dominated company. Yes, many women work here but they aren't promoted (unless they're bullies), they're under paid, and they're ignored. I see a lot of turnover with the women I've worked with here

I could go on and on. I've been here for over five years. I know multiple people that are exhausted, miserable, and looking to get out.
Advice to Management
The new CEO needs to clean house - leaders at all levels, but especially the executives, need to be replaced

review_title: Great company if you enjoy long hours
pros: Great onboarding and training, colleagues are all very capable and friendly, culture of inclusiveness and teamwork, mgmt is approachable and wants to see you succeed, the company switched to WFH for Covid and I believe there are plans to make that permanent
cons:
Pay is great if based on a 40 hour work week, but our department consistently works 60-70 hours per week. The job is high stress and it is difficult to take vacation time. Most people work while on vacation. Bonus potential maxes out at 5%, which is low considering how much extra time and effort employees dedicate to their jobs.
Advice to Management
Working from home helps with work/life balance. Please continue with this model after Covid. Most employees would be happy with a day or two in the office, and WFH the rest of the week. Hire more people so the workload is spread out such that people can complete work within 40 hours/week. Not adequately staffing and expecting salaried workforce to work an extra 20+ hours every week is exploitative. That would not fly in the EU.
Helpful

pros: Good benefits, friendly coworkers, lots to learn.
cons:

Also teach your district managers not to micromanage their team excessively. We make fee decisions as a result and cannot feel ownership of our territories. Also too much fear by DSM's of their Sales directors.
Advice to Management
Clean up your 25+ year tenure good old boy club of managers across the nation. These are the same guys that ran huge profit margins in the 90's and early 2000's, making it extremely difficult for current sales reps to walk into a prospect and not get ran out the restaurant. Take actual input from your associates and stop picking favorites to use as extreme examples of success to the rest of the salesforce (I ended up as one of them).They are terrified of rocking the boat.

pros:
Pay WAS good, previous commision structure was lucrative IF you knew how to sell.
I was already used to the 7 day a week on-call environment that comes with foodservice, the long hours, the unreasonable and intrusive micromanagement, the abusive alcoholic chefs and customers, and the unwillingness of many customers to pay for long digested and forgotten food. My previous 30 plus years in this industry had made me well accustomed to that.
cons:
Until I started reading the hundreds of negative reviews from current and former salespeople, I thought the nonsense I witnessed and experienced was mostly local, Now I know it's national. Let's get started:
I was recruited from a competitor. After my no compete expired, I was able to bring over a couple of million in business to Sysco. Now that I was let go because of Covid (more on that lie later), those customers are now off-limits to me at a new job, if I could get one. There is a pattern of bringing on reps from competing firms and then divvying up the spoils amongst their favorite MA's when those reps are shoved out.
The Three Stooges could be a more effective leadership team. There is ZERO leadership. Opco management just rolls the corporate dictums downhill, no matter how out of touch and stupid they are. Their days are spent knitting butt covers for themselves, and micromanaging the sales team through 360 (salesforce). They care more about process than results. If you sat on your laptop entering garbage about what you supposedly did, and where you went, that was more important than actually creating results.
Favoritism: Lots of it. There was a nucleus of employees who had survived the various coups over the years, and they do very well being handed the accounts that are taken from those who leave. I had 5 route splits in 2 years, with the easiest to service, high margin accounts given to underperforming (but buddy/buddy with manager) reps benefitting. I was given the accounts that were bungled and manhandled by others along with the negative history constantly.
Despite all these negatives, because I have over 30 years experience in this field, I was able to overcome these hurdles, and actually made "Chairman's Club", a supposed honor at Sysco. Less than 6 months later, when the shamdemic came along, that piece of paper came in handy during the TP shortage! I made the company over 850k in profit-dollars, and I was kicked to the curb. I wasn't on a plan, had no discipline issues, but I am over 60, and I made too much money for the new pay plan... They fired us on a surprise video call en masse, and then just like Mission Impossible, my laptop went dead. In order to get the severance package, we had to sign off that there was no age discrimination (there OBVIOUSLY was) and had this not been such a financial shock, I would have retained a lawyer.
I could keep going, but the last thing is something their stock holders should be aware of. Their pricing is literally crooked. Unless a rep manages avery single price every week, the "system" will jab a customer with 70 dollars a box on potatoes that should be 20. You are trained and encouraged to participate in shady schemes like changing prices by switching numbers around. No matter how high your margins are, it's never enough, until a customer catches you, and then the clowns in management go to the customer, hat in hand, blaming the rep, and transferring the account, all to start the rip-off all over. The internal "pads" are the highest I've ever seen in my long career, as much as 40% on sysco branded items, even commodities that all come from the same sources. We were always 2 steps behind the market when prices dropped, and raised them ahead of the actual increases. I had to spend more time defending the company's nonsense than selling. You also have to compete with all your co-workers for new business. I've never seen anything like it. Literally dog eat dog, with the favorite lap dogs usually winning with management help. I had numerous prospects taken away after weeks or months of work and given to their pets.
Advice to Management
Advice? GFYS! Oh, and stop rearranging the deck chairs, this ship is going down as soon as Amazon decides you're next!
Helpful (2)

pros: Fortune 500 Company is a plus
cons:
Pay vs. other Fortune based on leveling
Lack of diversity
Advice to Management
In my OpCo, diversity is a huge issue. Unless you are in the warehouse (90% African American) or driving a truck (75% African American) diversity doesn’t exist in supervisor or management levels. Warehouse and Transportation are low level from line manual labor position. If the national population is roughly 12% AA why is it okay that this PUBLICLY traded company suffers from diversity. Look at the senior leaders in corporate on the company website. No ethic diversity. Of the 70+ OpCo presidents, only 1 is AA. That is not representative of the people who buy your stock or eat your food. I have asked the question. I got this canned, “We are not were we want to be but we are working to be better.” Don’t insult my intelligence. Your passivity in this are creates a bad culture create. Be socially responsible! No excuses, be better! Bet results oriented vs. dodged the inquiries. What is your response to the Sysco? You respond to other reviews on Glassdoor to manage your brand. Silence is an answer. That numbers and trends don’t lie!

pros: They encourage creativity, love questions, and very flexible once you start producing. Sysco is the strongest food distribution company in the States with functional online tools for associates and customers. Ongoing training and lots of communication are helpful. The network of contacts you can build with customers, co-workers, and vendors is countless. They offer some benefits.
cons:
Very big company with lots of layers. Quick decisions are rare. Only the top 5-10% are tapping into the comp plan, you need to be writing a ton of business to make 10k a month. Moderate base plus monthly bonus for the rest. It is not a high paying sales position for most of the reps, but I heard it use to be. No car or phone allowance while majority of the work is on the road. 6 day a week job, sometimes 7 if the customers you're servicing need you on a Saturday. The good health insurance plan is expensive, $10,000 a year for a family.
Advice to Management
Its time for a more lucrative comp plan.
Helpful (1)

review_title: Good if you get good accounts to start
pros: Good benefits. 2 weeks vacation but also personal days, sick days, and holidays. Averages to about 3+ weeks in the beginning. Feel self employed and empowered to be as successful as you can. Good job to network in and build positive relationships internally and externally with customers. Intense training program which can be overwhelming but is helpful especially if you are new to outside sales. Lots of resources at your disposal.
cons:
When you receive a territory you are either given accounts from someone that has left or accounts they create for you, which are normally low performing accounts. So you could be in a financial hole from the start if your accounts are low performers. Communication is below average and at be ready to wait for answers. Customer service is lacking unless you are a high buying customer.
Advice to Management
Understand that in the end results come down to numbers. With such a large company feel there is opportunity to evaluate more in detail performance of the employee.
Helpful

pros: Fantastic Training program. They really invest in the training of their sales staff with a world class training program.
cons:
1. Have to use your own vehicle, with no mileage reimbursement
2. Have to use your own cell phone with no reimbursement
3. benefits are "average" at best
4. lots of micromanaging
5. Promise a base salary at hiring, when you complete training the gets greatly reduced as you move to the commission plan
6. products are overpriced with too much company padding. you cannot sell the products at a competitive price and actually make any money
7. company is solely focused on income. you're just a number despite them saying it's a family atmosphere.
8. if you aren't one of the golden children you will not receive good opportunities
9. EVERYONE is your competition!
Advice to Management
Streamline communication. Give middle management more control, and follow through on your promises. Change the title from marketing associate to territory manager. When you fire people due to a crisis this makes it incredibly difficult to explain to future employers that you didn't actually do marketing!

review_title: Laid off on a conference call
pros: Until the Coronavirus, I genuinely enjoyed what we did. We worked very hard, but the payoff was satisfaction and family. We had each others backs, until the virus.
cons:
Once the virus hit (this is after we had a bad few months in the stock market and replaced the ceo) we all saw that the honesty was gone. Our bosses said one thing (talked smack about a competitor that had to lay off staff) and literally the next day they tell 80% to get on one conference call, and 20% on the other. Then they read of a piece of paper how all of us were fired. On a conference call.. wow... that’s like breaking up a marriage via text. So basically the stock slipped before the virus, the virus gave them an opportunity to downsize like they did last year just with less scrutiny.
Advice to Management
Hard to make money when you lay off the ones making good money for the company.

7. Job requires heavy traveling....company does not pay mileage
8. When starting out, the current reps get to get rid of their 'crap' and you
 get stuck with making the best of it.
9. Sales meetings every Friday...way too many
Advice to Management
Address the above 1-9

review_title: An acceptable place to work, but there are better options
pros: The front-line supervisors are tremendously dedicated to what they do. The truck fleet equipment was newer and better than other food industry competitors.
cons:
Advancement to and within management is determined mostly by longevity and occasionally by pure favoritism. This is as opposed to actual expertise or leadership ability. Information technology [IT] systems company-wide are embarrassingly antiquated, and there seems to be an overall lack of understanding within the company regarding the need to update its IT solutions to maintain an edge in the industry and improve efficiencies (and therefore profits). IT support for existing equipment is also very poor.
Advice to Management
Stop reducing benefits for current employees as a simplistic cost-cutting measure. The money saved is lost many times over through attrition since well-qualified workers and leaders move to other companies with better compensation and benefits packages.
Helpful
Sysco Response

review_title: Great Benefits, Good Money, On Call 27/7
pros: Success determined by your motivation, territory and what you inherit. Top notch continuous training. Tools and resources available to get the job done and increase sales. Make your own schedule based around customer visits with flexibility in territory.
cons:
Stressful situations with cut off times, set delivery days, credit situations, weekly price changes and out of stock items. You are on call 24/7, and work weekends and holidays. Sysco requires all marketing associates to pay out of pocket for a higher insurance coverage in case of an accident on the job, they also do not provide you with a phone or car and do not have any allowances what-so-ever for everyday necessities.

Less promo's forcing sales on specific items

pros: Free Parking. and Few cool people in the office.
cons:
1. The Financial person is a weirdo and never approve anything on time. Be careful. People are watching you in the office and then call your supervisor.
2. Not 1 person job. The last 3 techs left this company in 10 or 11 months. and if you ask this question, they will tell you this "The last tech never said NO, and they got overwhelmed." They say that all the time but is no true.
3. At least my manager played favoritism. I completed more than 5 long projects and never received employee on the month, however, if one of his favorite tech install anything or travel somewhere they get employee of the month.
4. Prepared to work on multiples projects without a warning.
5. Old hardware with lack of space. When I started it was only 100GB now is 200GB.
6. Printers are truly a mess.
7. Devices in operations are full of dust, you will get sick guarantee.
8. Tickets in ServiceNow are a joke. Nobody works on those. Only tier 1 and the tech on site.
9. Prepare to take 3 and 4 meetings per day. Useless, not related to your job, but is mandatory because you are the new person.

I can say more awful that happened to me when I was there but go and see for yourself. I could say that 60% of the people there are not professional at all.
Advice to Management
Nothing, you will not listen.
Helpful

pros:
Flexible schedule*

*sometimes

Met a few good people.
cons:
This list could go on and on. The pay was subpar (sales) and commissions are a joke. Seriously. They complicate the pay structure so the sales team doesn't realize how much they're being ripped off. The management is like a group of guys that graduated from clown college. The managers professionalism is that of a snake oil salesmen. Restaurants need food, Sysco sells it. It should be that simple, but they convolute the process with unnecessary micromanagement. The encouragement to lie to customers is strong within the 4 walls of Sysco.
 IF you drink the cult Kool-Aid that Sysco feeds their zombified sales veterans, you have a chance at staying in their prison-job. If you make it clear how idiotic their ideas are, you put a bullseye on your back. The management expects the saleswomen to sleep with them, which makes the monthly sales meetings very awkward. 
 Once I realized how little the DSMs make, (District Sales Managers), I realized this is pennies compared to other industries. Save yourself the time and frustration and look at other employment opportunities. Serious sales professionals will be miserable with Sysco. 

Actual sales talent among the whole sales team in West Texas is almost non-existent. Their "training" isn't to better their sales team. The training is just mindless preaching and knock-off TED talks. I met maybe 3 REAL sales professionals among the group.
Best decision I made was to take my leave. Wasted good time. If I could've rated a 0☆, I would've.
Advice to Management
This portion of the review is useless for Sysco. Management doesn't take advice. Management believes they have all the answers. They'll soon be regretting their ego once Amazon gets it's food delivery business model in place. Just a matter of time...

review_title: Great growth opportunity but is it worth it?
pros: Great Company to have a career growth.
cons:
Being in low margin high volume business is without a doubt a high stress environment. There is no work flexibility or any resemblance of balance.
Advice to Management
There is a lot of waste with archaic processes and systems. Instead of looking at efficiencies by "consolidating work" with lowly paid and lowly skilled people, invest on highly skilled and motivated associates. We're tripping over dollars to pick up pennies. Also, google 'burn out syndrome' ... I said it here so don't act surprised when you see high exodus and absences.

review_title: Lack of diversity at the top
pros: You have the opportunity to move around to learn more about other teams and commute is great.
cons:
Managers whether good or bad can influence your growth opportunity. They promote managers without providing them with the skills of a manager. Promotions are based on “if I like you” not “can you perform the job”. Lack of diversity has help drive this environment. Refer to the board of directors...until there is change there it will never foster downward.
Advice to Management
Create a management program, provide better benefits (a mother should not have to return to work after they exhausted their sick and vacation time), implement a work from home day or 9/80s and allow for 360 review so employees do not experience poor management behavior.

review_title: Should have taken care of Employees
pros: Learned a lot in my time there
cons:
Did not allow sales to have an expense account or get reimbursed for travel, entertaining, gas, cell phone, ect. Sales Reps spend $20,000- $30,000/ year just to go to work everyday. Please keep that in mind when you go to work there. I worked there for over 10 years and was very successful. I thought I was going to retire from Sysco a few years ago, but the culture changed and Sysco didn't change with the times. there are too many jobs out there that will pay the same or more and cover all of your expenses.
Advice to Management
Change your mentality. Its not fair for employees to spend that much money out of their own pocket. Give your sales reps Cell Phones and company cars. Allow them to expense entertaining customers and going on prospect calls. If you don't you will continue to see good employees walk out the door and new ones not want to work there at all.

Managers have it worse than the selectors so just keep your heads up and try not to give up

review_title: You Get Out What You Put In
pros: Decent compensation, great benefits, stock purchase plan, great industry training, flexible working hours if you manage your time correctly.
cons:
Demanding hours at times, depending on your location, weekend routes may need attention on Saturdays & Sundays
Advice to Management
Put great managers in place and train them to be great leaders, always look to promote from within first and show your team they are appreciated. Open and honest dialogue within teams should be encouraged to retain good people. When I was at Sysco, about 50% of my 12 person region talked amongst the group privately about interviewing elsewhere and wanting to leave. Six of twelve. That's a very low satisfaction rate. Open conversation may have prevented some losses on our team.

review_title: STAY AWAY; Very unprofessional and highly discriminatory organization
pros: Fortune 100 status and decent benefits. High standards for their products are also impressive. Good training program when you have competent people to implement such when onboarding. Great career potential for those starting out early career.
cons:
Two of the OpCos I dealt with were VERY problematic. There are a group of highly uneducated, ignorant, and unprofessional people in leadership who think that discriminating against women, insulting candidates, putting employees at safety risks (and your leadership laughs about them), and manipulating situations to get what they want are "good ideas" and there are no consequences for such. If you are fresh out of college or a kitchen and have limited to no corporate work experience, come here because you probably don't know any better. If you are a well-educated, intelligent, and self-respecting human being, you'll find out quickly that - despite the Fortune 100 status - you'll see right through the BS, egos, and valid liability issues in no time. The organization proudly stresses the companies 5 core values repeatedly (particularly integrity) but does not abide by them whatsoever. One of the OpCos states it is female friendly despite teams of men do not treat you with any respect, exclude you from team meetings, and it is a predominantly male dominated "good old boys" club. This is - hands down - the worst company I have ever dealt with in over 30 years of working with a variety of companies, roles and geographic locations.
Advice to Management
Please retrain yourselves on the company values, abide by them, and set good examples as ALL good leaders do. Corporate - please investigate your leadership at OpCos and what's really happening before someone hits you with a valid lawsuit because your leadership parties do not have the intellect to understand liability and that their choices do have consequences. Be accountable for your actions when you hire a person willing to relocate from out of the area and you grossly fail to produce what you sold as a viable position and organization. Lastly, please keep your egos where they need to be - you are only selling food; not performing brain surgery and saving human lives. This company has great potential; unfortunately, it has a long way to go to be a great and respected leader like others in the Fortune 100 and 500 status clubs.
Helpful (1)

This company has great potential; unfortunately, it has a long way to go to be a great and respected leader like others in the Fortune 100 and 500 status clubs.

pros: There are some very nice people here who love their jobs and the company. Pay wasn't too bad, and there are some other perks. The company acts like they care.

Slow. This place is so slow. Apart from having the 39348380 meetings just to decide to change the roll of toilet paper, nobody wants to make decisions on their own. And when decisions are made, good lord they are bad.
Complex. This place has two different "god complexes". First is that people in positions of authority are for some reason treated like saints or gods. Seriously, it is just odd. The other is the Sysco beleif that they can do no wrong and that every supplier is there just for them. Surprised more of the major suppliers don't leave.
Final straw is beating the markets expectations and continuing to lay off large amounts of people while not fundamentally changing how they do business.

When the market disruption comes, you are not going to be able to respond. You are too slow and too full of yourself.

pros: Intimate working environment. Good employees
cons:

Advice to Management
Advice to actual Sysco management is to take a closer look at what is happening at your specialty branch. Look beyond the graphs and numbers to see how the people working there are actually feeling, thinking and experiencing. It does not go unnoticed that the European Imports branch is attempting to post job openings under Sysco to make themselves look "better" because the European Imports rating by employees (current and past) is horrible. I'm sure Sysco is a good company to work for but the "take over" mentality and dehumanizing of the people during such a period is the stuff of movies.

pros: You have a lot of flexibility in this job to the point where you almost make your own schedule. Also, having a $52,000 base is good for a salesperson coming right out of college.
cons:
Individuality and varying management styles are not considered. If an employee isn't motivated by money it is hard to maintain happiness in the position. This job is a constant beat down because of a lack of stability. You never know when you are going to walk into a customer and them leave you. A significant amount of this position is also out of your control (late trucks, customers not paying their invoices) but it effects your pay and bonuses. Your travel/phone expenses are not compensated - I have put 40,000 miles on my car in 15 months. Finally, the systems and commissions are always changing. There are so many moving parts that it is hard to keep updated.
Advice to Management
Employees were people prior to taking the position with your company and they deserve to be treated with respect and dignity. They should not be told that they are replaceable on a regular basis.

Managers who don't know what their employees are doing and base performance on limited info, inhibiting growth by keeping people jobs they are good at instead of teaching new things, do not listen to feedback from mangers and employees even though they are continually asked. Plenty of learning opportunities available just no time to do them. Moving to centralization is killing morale for workings not at corporate and at corporate as well.
Advice to Management
Provide broader opportunities for growth. Do not require managers approval for moving within company in case the employee is being kept from advancing. Provide time for employees to have professional development hours.
Helpful (1)

review_title: Taking the personalization OUT of the company!
pros: Large company, good benefits, salary in line with market
cons:
Cutting jobs left and right. Associate morale at an all time low. Turning so “corporate” that the reason our customer base loved us (our service level) is the one thing they are destroying by centralizing everything. They aren’t realizing that the food industry is very different in different areas of the country. Corporate and their “think tank groups” are ruining this once wonderful company!!!
Advice to Management
Stop centralizing and start thinking of your dedicated and valued associates! Think of the individual service to your customers before you lose sales!!!

pros: If it were possible to put no stars, I would. Good pay and benefits if your Human resource team does their job. However, I was supposed to have insurance benefits when I broke my leg while I worked there, but ended up having to front the $40,000 bill when HR didn’t do their job. Make sure the information they give you is accurate and follow-up!!!!
cons:
Hostile work environment if you don’t come from within, regardless of your skills and abilities. Upper management will steal your ideas and call them their own if they’re good; if they are bad, they will throw you under the bus at every opportunity they have.
Advice to Management
Tom Bene - consider cleaning house at Sysco Central CA (all upper management) and putting good leaders in place, the kind that promote a positive and transparent work environment. An environment that everyone can grow in, not just promoting themselves by stepping on the necks of the lower ranks of the organizational chart to get there.

review_title: Know what your Getting into as a Marketing Associate
pros: Company Phone, Mileage Reimbursement, Immersive sales training, Lots of free food.
cons:
Work life vs Personal life, Management speaks out of both sides of mouth, they preach work, life , balance but at the same time work is always the priority. Your only true day off is Saturday, don't kid your self you work sunday's! These Managers love to hear themselves talk. Meeting every Friday going over all the wrongs your doing in the field and then a GSM Meeting at the local OPCO usually a few hours drive to go over whatever new worthless items your will have to push on your clients. Lastly last weeks numbers are history, if you did great last week you can easily be the scape goat this week. Pay is OK but does not equal the amount of work you will put out. You will be at the will of you clients and they are demanding and petty. Asking for PTO is like pulling teeth from these managers, and yes you will work every holiday! Pay is around $51,500 they way to above is to sell more than your salary and you will never have a set salary one year it migh be $65k next year your back to the base of 51k. You are at the will of your clients, this is a nickel and dime business your clients will stop buying from you for a simple reason as Eggs going up by 5 cents this week. If this in anyway does not sound like your cup of tee.... keep looking.
Advice to Management
All you Regional, District Sales managers etc.. You sell groceries your are not selling nuclear fission. "KISS" Keep it simple stupids! Respect the time and personal time of your marketing associate and you guys are not Tony Robbins with these ridiculous speeches that probably take you hours to come up with. review_title: Delivery Driver- Great if you can handle it.
pros: As others have said good money and benefits. If you can go without a portion of money each quarter you can buy stock at a 15% discount and either save it for dividends or sell back later. Pretty much your own boss and as long as you do a good job keeping up with the work you will be mostly left alone. Get catered breakfasts and parties occasionally like Royals games, Worlds of Fun etc. Good job security as long as you are safe and reasonably keep up with the work you will be completely safe in you job.
cons:
You will work for those money/benefits. Think lifting 15000-25000lbs of product every day putting it on a two-wheeler and pushing it in a store. Turnover is fairly high as most people who try end up quitting because of workload; so during busy times you might have to go out and do extra or have extra added onto your route.
Advice to Management
This is more complicated as it is kind of a cache 22. It can be irritating to see new guys get bonuses while us older employees that have stuck it out get no more compensation other than more vacation and more seniority to bid on routes that come available. However, if they don't get more people hired on the burden shifts more towards the rest of us who are still there. So I see their point in doing so.

pros: Benefits, Compensation, Performance Incentives (dip payment)
cons:
Seniority rules sound business decisions: senior drivers have best equipment while they’re off, trucks sit empty. Trucks aren’t assigned to size of load, they’re assigned by seniority. Refer units have over 32K hours, don’t get colder than 52 degrees, mass amounts of product wasted. Customers extremely unhappy with level of service and delivered product. Management allows the employees to run the operations. Drivers call in based on their load regularly. Drivers hoard delivery equipment based on convenience not on necessity. Have been approved for dip payment but not earning it because routing times are off; I consistently finish my route hours early. It is the most poorly ran operation I have ever worked for and I have worked for other Sysco operations and have been in delivery for 20+ years.
Advice to Management
The Phoenix AZ operation can be great, it has the potential, but they’re are senior leadership that have become complacent or are close to retirement and don’t want to change anything. It needs a complete overhaul, and it needs to start at the top. If things don’t change, Sysco AZ will continue experiencing high turnover and poor customer experiences.

pros: Learn multiple skills, work with good people, paychecks do not bounce.
cons:
Not a place you can grow, management opportunities are limited, hourly employees do not get raises and very little overtime. If you want an 8-5 job and have no aspirations of ever doing any better financially than what you make on day 1, then this may be a good fit for you. Otherwise, its just a job until you find another one. Also, corporate leaders of the company have made it completely impossible to apply accountability to the employees due their minimum staff maximum effort philosophy. The only real rule inside an OPCO is hurry up. Safety and accountability take a back seat to production. Very stressful environment if you are in maintenance and have to clean up or fix everybody else's mess.
Advice to Management
Lose the ONE Sysco mentality, it doesn't work. Every OPCO is different and needs to be ran accordingly. Revamp the engineering standards pay plan and account for cleaning, accidents, and equipment/employee short comings. Not every day is your best day, things happen. And finally, if you keep hiring cheap labor to replace competent labor, then your remaining competent labor is going continue to leave the company and all you have left is cheap, unqualified associates. Pay your people in positions of responsibility what they deserve and not "market value" or Sysco will continue to lose these people at the current unsustainable rate.
Helpfu

pros: Good Money, Plenty of hours, Great Medical Benefits(because you're subject to being injured on the job).
cons:
Worked for the Saint Charles MO location for six months. This has been by far the WORST company I have worked for since becoming a CDL driver. Where do I start? Very unorganized with scheduling, from week to week you don't know what your off day will be. You work very long hours, and once you get home you have no energy to do anything, but eat and go to sleep. Management text you the NIGHT BEFORE to tell you "stay home tomorrow." Sometimes the text that you are off the following day can come anywhere between 8-9 pm, and to them this is normal. They DO NOT care about you as an employee, they only care our their products being delivered to their retailers. If you call and alert management that you're about to die, they're going to ask you can you delivery their products first and then you can die. This job is very, very strenuous on your body, Throughout the six month I was employed with Sysco I have acquired to many aches and pains. Most of the Drivers that have been with the company for years are limping and beat down. Many guys have gone out on lead due to injury. I've watched them ask drivers to clean out old products at restaurants, which we are not supposed to do) just to appease the restaurants managers. Long story short, if you want to feel like you're just a pawn this is the place for you. I don't recommend anyone working for a company such as Sysco.

review_title: Missing the mark and will be left behind
pros: Setting your own schedule and having a flexible day. Limited supervision throughout the week. Not having to work at a desk.
cons:
No life/work balance; you work on weekends, evenings, holidays, days off, sick days....oh you took off for vacation? Sysco work goes with you! Company is so large yet so dysfunctional. Should have their main focus be on being a good delivery company, but process is so old and outdated they cannot get the simplest of tasks done with any reliability. Most of your time is spent putting out fires instead of selling or providing value to customers.
Advice to Management
Please stop the constant work day Fridays and monthly GSM's. They aren't making us want to work harder or providing any motivation. Just soul sucking. Mid-level management is so afraid of upper management in the opco that they don't speak their mind. They just become yes men, saying whatever the top people want to hear. Often initiatives are rolled out without any thought or process in place to make them work which just demoralizes sales. No budget throughout the year for any perks makes it hard to want to jump through the silly hoops they put in place. Pay is low compared to competitors and new people are being brought on with a higher salary making it really hard on the others. Doesn't matter if you work your whole life at Sysco, if they are done with you, you are escorted out, even with 33 years of employment with out even a mention. Sad.

cons:

2) Only two weeks (10 days) vacation for the first 5-7 years of employment. Vacation time and Sick time should just be PTO but it isn't.

review_title: Used to be a good company but has gone down hill every year.
pros: Decent pay with decent benefits for a job that requires no degree.
cons:
If you look at Forbe's toxic workplace this place hits every one on the list. Favoritism is rampant as rules get bent and broken depending on who you are.
Absolutely no communication between the workers and management, HR and the higher ups could care less about your problems. No work life balance since you're so exhausted you can't do anything on the weekends and have no time when you get off work. The equipment is old and they refuse to replace it, you red tag something and it takes days or weeks to fix it. The training program is very poor and many people walkout or quit within the first few days. There's no advancement despite them saying career advancement, you either pick or drive until you die. This is a temporary job as you can't do it forever because it's so hard on your body. Everyone hates the place but they have bills to pay so they can't quit. They talk down to you like you're an idiot and you don't know anything because they don't trust their employees. I wouldn't recommend this job to anyone.
Advice to Management
You need to communicate better. Instead of sending out 150 e-mails a day go down on the floor and ask what's wrong and here's the important part management, are you listing? HOW ABOUT YOU ACTUALLY TAKE INITIATIVE AND CHANGE THE THINGS THAT WE'RE HAVING PROBLEMS WITH. All you do is tell us the same things day in and day out at the pre-shift meetings and nothing gets done. The quarterly meetings are a waste of time it's the same info every time. you need to take better care or your workers because soon there's going to be no one that wants to work there.

review_title: Fantastic example of white male privilege
pros: Free food, decent healthcare. Many of the employees are great, but are overworked and underpaid.
cons:
Predominately male and white. The company wants the exact same type of employee at every location in an effort to justify paying the lowest salary. A sales employee in California is expected to make the same salary as their counterpart in Alabama, even though the costs of living are vastly different. Employees are classified in tiers and salaries are capped. So if someone were content with being an administrative assistant for the rest of her career, and she has been with the company for 10+ years, her salary would NEVER increase. She does not get a salary increase for merit or cost of living. Bonuses are for executives only, and those come at the expense of their employees. 
Corporate has made some astounding and extremely expensive errors over the years. The spent over a Billion dollars trying to convert their system to SAP. During the beginning of that transition they decided to fire all of their local IT personnel and hire a firm in India (known for their H-1B violations) to reduce the cost of the transition because they mistakenly believe that all of their employees are computer literate and IT is easy. Sysco was very, very, very wrong. They had to bring back and hire new IT associates at every opco. Instead of a smooth transition to SAP, they had to revert to the "old" AS400 system.
Sysco also believed that as an entity, it can do no wrong and that they could easily have a merger with the second largest food supplier in the nation, US Foods, and everyone would love the idea. It was obviously going to create a monopoly and the FTC agreed. The merger was cancelled, which cost Sysco even more money. It probably doesn't help that Sysco and US Foods tend to "swap" employees on a regular basis.
Recent changes also led to the mass exodus of many talented, intelligent, hard-working and loyal employees. Many great employees are still there, but are expected to now do the work of 2-3 people without a salary increase. The only "incentive" is that they "get" is to keep their job.
Advice to Management
Learn to listen to all employees, not just managers trying to save themselves. Pay people what they're worth and stop trying to shove human beings into your tiny, unimaginative stereotypical boxes.
Helpful (7
advice_to_mgmt: Learn to listen to all employees, not just managers trying to save themselves. Pay people what they're worth and stop trying to shove human beings into your tiny, unimaginative stereotypical boxes.

review_title: Corporate IT Dept - Great benefits, good culture (mostly)
pros:
-Great benefits including "extras" outside of the typical insurance/401k structure
-Most senior management in IT are great leaders, empowering and motivational
-A culture of pitching in together and doing it right, big emphasis on ethics and code of conduct
-Dynamic environment (if you enjoy a challenge and shifting gears)
-Values diversity, longevity, and employee growth - lots of opportunities to grow your skills in leadership, job-related areas, and elsewhere
-Some positions compensation is above market

Overall, I think the pros outweigh the cons for my personal taste. I work well in an environment that changes - over the 3 years that I've worked in IT at Sysco, we've changed our management structure 3 times, changed IT strategy at least twice, and adopted new methodologies twice. Communication can be a challenge, but the change is generally well done so as along as you are comfortable switching gears, you'll be fine. Sysco offers a great benefits package including decent vacation/time-off and good "perks" like holiday hams and employee purchasing. The company also values employee learning and growth, and puts major effort into offering coaching/learning opportunities, especially if you are interested in management roles or learning better leadership. Compensation seems to be above market in some positions while under market in others, so it's hit or miss.
cons:
-Dynamic environment (if you don't adapt well to change)
-IT specific: Very siloed, other departments will do their own thing, not much knowledge transfer between departments so you often compete with each other for resources unknowingly
-IT specific: support is mostly managed services, and the companies providing those services are not very focused on "the customer experience", so you often have to clean up their work
-Technology is ancient
-Some mid-level managers are inflexible and demotivating, leading with more of a carrot/stick mentality.
-IT specific: There's still a big grudge when Sysco unilaterally laid off most of the IT department (and brought in managed services) about 5 years ago or so, so those who have been around since before then often have a bone to pick and get very disgruntled quickly. It can be hard to work with those managers at times because they're too busy being upset about the decision made, and not interested in collaboration/furthering the business
-IT specific: Because most roles are filled by managed services companies, career growth within IT is very limited unless you go into management
-(might be a con to you) Often expected to go the extra mile, work outside of the typical 9-5

The cons are generally limited to roles that require collaboration and communication cross-functionally within the IT department. If your role will not require working with other groups often, then they may not apply much to you. Also, if you are looking for more technical roles, and are not interested in moving in management, the career opportunities are severely limited, though I see some of that changing in emerging technologies like cyber security and cloud architecture. 

In IT especially, you're often expected to put in extra work to meet deadlines or support major releases in off-hours. You also tend to get too many assignments, so your work/life balance may suffer a bit. I've noticed this in other departments, too, that the expectation is to do what needs to be done - if you're a "roll your sleeves up, get to work" kind of person, this shouldn't be a problem. However, if you're motivated by a more structured environment with clear roles/responsibilities and boundaries, then this may not be the right culture for you.

Unrelated to IT specifically, the environment is extremely dynamic which can be a con if you are not flexible/adaptable. The company also uses very old technology as a backbone for its core systems, which can fail unexpectedly during business hours. Depending on your role, some of the systems you need to do your job may break once a week or once a month. However, support is usually pretty quick to get things working again (....unless you get one of the offshore groups, for some reason the company they picked to provide offshore support has no interest in comprehending problems, so they waste 2-3 days just trying to ask you the same questions over and over again)
Advice to Management
IT specific: Build more career paths within IT for entry level IT personnel that will move them into more technical roles. Encourage departments to work together instead of in a vacuum, so there's less frustration and competition for resources. Take a long hard look at the customer satisfaction rating of the managed services companies you contract with - they might offer great dev resources, but if the support/service is terrible, the rest of IT suffers.

Non-IT specific: More communication across all functional areas, more emphasis on building leadership skills with managers, especially mid-level managers.
Helpful (5
advice_to_mgmt:
IT specific: Build more career paths within IT for entry level IT personnel that will move them into more technical roles. pros: Since the beginning, John Baugh was the guiding force behind the founding of SYSCO. Baugh had grown up on a ranch near Waco, Texas, and got his start in the food business through a part-time job at a local A&P grocery store when he was in high school. He eventually founded Zero Foods Company of Houston, a Houston-based food distributor. In 1969 Baugh convinced the owners of eight other small food distributors to combine the nine companies, forming what he hoped to mold into a national food-service distribution organization, one that would be able to distribute any food despite its regional availability. The other eight original companies were: Frost-Pack Distributing Company (Grand Rapids, Michigan); Global Frozen Foods, Inc. (New York); Houston's Food Service Company (Houston); Louisville Grocery Company (Louisville, Kentucky); Plantation Foods (Miami, Florida); Texas Wholesale Grocery Corporation (Dallas); Thomas Foods, Inc. and its Justrite Food Service, Inc. subsidiary (Cincinnati); and Wicker, Inc. (Dallas). The combined 1969 sales for the nine founding companies were $115 million. Currently the vision is yet the same with the economic demands and crisis still yet SYSCO finds a way to stay above the rest.
cons:
The Cons are typical with any other company of such magnitude. When there is change it is not always pleasant and you will have a few employees who don't appreciate the decisions being made. But over-all SYSCO is a good company to work for.
Advice to Management
Being a new employee I don't really have too much to comment in this area.

Being a new employee I don't really have too much to comment in this area.
Helpfu

pros:
Great Pay
Local work

They don't lie when they say that it's hard work, for good money. Can make anywhere from 75k-105k a year, but you're gunna work your butt off for it.
cons:
Driver treatment
Work load
Days off (usually non-consecutive)

Until you get your own route, they call around 7-9pm to give you options for the next day's routes, but you were up at 2:30am to get there by 3:30 and worked a 12-16 hour day. Very little sleep. Your body is also destroyed, and if you work there a long time, assume you'll need new knees.
Advice to Management
For newer drivers, give them specific routes so they can sleep through the night, and give them 2 days off in a row to recuperate from the hard work week.

It was hard to get used to it, but once you do (usually takes a few months) and get your own route, it isn't terrible.
Helpfu

pros:
Free food
Easy parking
Casual attire, slippers are even ok!
cons:
No training...you can sit next to someone and watch them press buttons for how long...no training manual, NOTHING-thrown out to the wolves

LACK of professionalism-constantly talking about other (current & past employees), ones who are just 2 aisle away! Constant bad language and talking about topics that are NOT meant for the work place. Manager CONSTANTLY on her FB, personal email or texting

Disgusted with the furniture that we had to sit on/use. None are ergonomically correct, they are old and dirty

No organization-the phone will ring until someone gets it, if the other reps are typing an email, "reading a report", talking on their personal phone, texting or flirting with the will call guy forget about anyone answering the phone...oh and the manager, she will answer if she isn't running her mouth about basketball!
Advice to Management
Get some organization, to start maybe have one designated trainer and a manual.
Follow the Labor Board rules, breaks, lunch being able to take in peace, not asked questions about work, use professional language when interacting among each other.
Make a training manual
Get new or clean the chairs/desks you have there
Educate your the managers on professional, not everyone needs to be your best friend who wants to talk sports, facebook posts and other things found on the internet during work hours. Be professional, DRESS professional!
Watch the language spoken in CS. 
Be aware of what's REALLY going on under your roof at Sysco San Diego!
